Religious significance

[edit]

According to some Jewish and Muslim sources, Urfa is Ur Kasdim, the hometown of Abraham, the grandfather of Jacob. This identification was disputed by Leonard Woolley, the excavator of the Sumerian city of Ur in 1927 and scholars remain divided on the issue. Urfa is also one of several cities that have traditions associated with Job.

For the Armenians, Urfa has "great symbolic value" since it is believed that the Armenian alphabet was invented there.[52]

Politics

[edit]

See also: Şanlıurfa (electoral district)

Urfa is a stronghold of the governing Justice and Development Party and is sometimes called a "vote depot" for the party.[53][54]

From 2004 to 2014, Ahmet Eşref Fakıbaba served as mayor of Urfa for two terms.[53] A popular figure in Urfa politics, Fakıbaba first rose to prominence as Chief Physician at the Şanlıurfa SSK Hospital, a role which he held for 11 years.[53] In 2004 he ran as the AKP candidate in the mayoral election and won.[53] The AKP did not nominate Fakıbaba as their mayoral candidate in the 2009 local elections, saying that they had 70% of the vote in Urfa and could win the election if their candidate was a jacket.[53] However, Fakıbaba ran as an independent and won reelection to a second term.[53] He later joined the Felicity Party before rejoining the AKP in 2013.[53] In 2015, Fakıbaba was elected to the National Assembly as an AKP member, replacing previous Urfa MP Faruk Çelik.[53] He later resigned as MP in 2022.[53]

Demographics

[edit]

History

[edit]

The ethnic and religious demographics of the city have shifted over the centuries and were largely diverse. In ancient times, the region was mixed with Greeks, Arabs, Syrians, and Armenians.[7] At the time of the First Crusade, the majority of the population were either Armenian or Assyrian.

There was an ancient Jewish community in Urfa, with about 1,000 people by the 19th century. Most of them emigrated in 1896, fleeing the Hamidian massacres, and settling mainly in Aleppo, Tiberias and Jerusalem.[55] In 1910, Ely Bannister Soane wrote that apart from Turkish effendis, Urfa was populated by Arabs, Kurds and a large number of Armenians.[56] British forces reported a mixed pre-war population of Kurds, Turks and 7,500 Armenians.[57] The Armenian Patriarchate of Constantinople reported 25,000 to 30,000 Armenians in Urfa and its environs, on an overall population of 60,000.[55] According to Agha Petros, there were 7,200 Syriacs in the city of Urfa, and 8,000 in ten surrounding villages.[55] Joseph Tfinkdji reports 200 Chaldeans.[55] According to 1918 reports of the Urfa mutasarrifate, there were 33,000 Turks, 27,000 Kurds, 12,000 Arabs, 5,500 Armenians, 3,000 Assyrians, and 500 Jews in the central kaza.[58]

The Armenian and Assyrian Genocides, undertaken by Ottoman troops and Ottoman-sponsored militias such as the special organization,[59] led to the slaughter, deportation,[57] and ethnic cleansing of much of the Christian population of Urfa and the surrounding region. Following the establishment of the Republic of Turkey, most of the remaining non-Muslim population left the city due to continued persecution.[60]

Language

[edit]

In the early 19th century, the dominant language of the city was Turkish,[61] while Armenian, Syriac, Kurdish, Arabic, and Persian were also spoken. Armenians were observed to speak Turkish to strangers, while Assyrians spoke Arabic.[7]

Present-day

[edit]

Today, the city is mainly composed of Arabs and Kurds[62][63] as well as Turks.[64]

Syrian refugees

[edit]

Since the outbreak of the Syrian Civil War, large numbers of refugees from Syria have settled in Urfa because of its closeness to the border and opportunities for employment.[44]: 111–2 As of 2017, as many as 300,000 Syrians live in Urfa, out of the total population of 750,000 in the province.[65] As of 2014, about 79% of Syrian refugees in Urfa were Arabic-speakers, while the other 21% were Kurdish-speakers.[66]: 7

In general, Syrians in Urfa have clustered in areas where home rental prices are lower; typical rents range from 600 to 900 liras (as of 2019).[44]: 112, 22 These homes are often small, and often more than one nuclear family shares the same residence, so a 100-140-square-meter may accommodate 6–17 people.[44]: 122 Syrians with the lowest incomes are most heavily concentrated in run-down neighborhoods with a lot of squatting that were previously inhabited mostly by poor people who had moved to Urfa from the countryside.[44]: 112 Often, they are in outlying neighborhoods far from the city center.[67] The largest number of Syrians in Urfa are in the Haliliye district, where they are especially concentrated in the neighborhoods (mahalles) of Devteşti, Ahmet Yesevi, Süleymaniye, Bağlarbaşı, Şehitlik, Cengiz Topel, Şair Nabi, Yeşildirek, İpekyolu, Sancaktar, İmam Bakır and Yavuz Selim.[44]: 119 The second-highest concentration is in Eyyübiye, whose neighborhoods (mahalles) with the highest concentrations of Syrians are Eyyüpnebi, Hayati Harrani, Eyüpkent, Akşemsettin, Yenice, Muradiye, Direkli and Kurtuluş.[44]: 118–9 In both cases, the Syrians here tend to prefer single-story residences where rents are not too high.[44]: 118–9 The third urban district of Urfa, Karaköprü, has a much smaller Syrian presence.[44]: 120 This area has been built up significantly in recent decades, with lots of luxury multi-story residences with high rents preferred by middle- and high-income residents.[44]: 120 The Syrians who live here mostly had relatively high pre-war incomes.[44]: 120 They are clustered in Maşuk, Karşıyaka, Akbayır and Şenevler.[44]: 120 As of 2014, the largest concentrations of Syrians in the city were in the mahalles of Hayati Harrani (165 families), Bağlarbaşı (115), Devteşti (105), Ahmet Yesevi (91), and Eyyüpnebi (90 families).[66]: 10

Syrian refugees in Urfa often struggle with financial difficulties and unemployment.[44]: 122 The language barrier hinders integration into the surrounding community, and many Syrians tend to form their own communities and interact less with Turkish locals.[44]: 122 Many Syrians in Urfa run their own businesses; workplaces belonging to Syrian refugees are clustered around Şehit Nusret Caddesi and Atatürk Boulevard, Sarayönü and Divanyolu Streets, and Haşimiye Meydan.[44]: 122 Many Syrians are also self-employed as street vendors, selling food, clothes, toys, and other items.[65]

Before 2017, relations were relatively friendly between Syrians and Turks, but after 2017 relations began to deteriorate as there was a growing perception among Turks that Syrians were to blame for economic stagnation.[44]: 122 The rapid increase in Syrian-owned businesses in Urfa, depressed wages for workers, and a perception that Syrians are "cheap labor" have all contributed to anti-Syrian sentiment among Turks.[44]: 121 Some Turks also resent the fact that Syrian refugees have free access to healthcare and education.[44]: 112 In July 2019, local authorities removed all Arabic-language signs on Syrian-owned businesses in Urfa and made Turkish-language signs mandatory.[44]: 122

Economy

[edit]

As of 2018, the average per capita income in Urfa is $4,400 USD per year.[68] As of 2018, unemployment in Urfa is 18%, among young people it is 35%.[68]

Urfa is a center of footwear production in the region,[68] and around 5,000 people are employed in this sector.[69]: 15 The Istanbul-based shoe retailer FLO, owned by the Ziylan Group, opened a shoe factory in Urfa in 2012.[70] As of 2018, this factory employed 900 people and was the largest footwear factory in the region,[68] producing 1.8 million pairs of shoes per year.[71] FLO was planning to open a second factory, employing 1,500 more people, in the city in early 2019.[68] According to the province governor Abdullah Erin, there were also plans to open some 13 more shoe factories in the Organized Industrial Zone by 2023, employing as many as 20,000 people and producing 30 million pairs of shoes annually.[68]

Urfa is a major producer of pistachio nuts, with 29.7 million trees in the whole province producing 38,576 tons of pistachios in 2021.[72] However, most processing is done in Gaziantep, which is the other main pistachio producer in Turkey.[72] Both cities' pistachios have geographical indications under different names for different cultivars, with Urfa's officially known as the "Urfa flax village pistachio" (Urfa keten köyneği fıstığı).[72]

Handicrafts

[edit]

Urfa has a rich tradition of handicrafts: coppersmiths, furriers, weavers and carpetmakers, felt makers, saddle makers, and jewelers all form part of this tradition.[73]: 369 Historically, the various trades had their own bazaars where artisans sold their wares.[73]: 369 In the 21st century, however, these handicrafts have been on the decline, and new generations are generally not learning them.[73]: 371

Copper-smithing is relatively prosperous among Urfa's handicrafts, although demand has fallen in favor of more contemporary décor.[73]: 370 Many coppersmiths have left the profession altogether, and those who remain often face declining incomes.[73]: 370 Jewelry making also remains a thriving business; its continued importance is partly because of traditional wedding customs that are still practiced.[73]: 370 The making of prayer beads (tespih) also continues in Urfa, with craftsmen working particularly around the Gümrük Han and the shopping areas around Balıklıgöl.[73]: 370 Woodcarvers, although few in number, are still in demand for restoration of old buildings.[73]: 370 A few furriers and saddle makers also continue to ply their trades in the city.[73]: 371

Artisanal leather tanning, on the other hand, is no longer practiced in Urfa, and new apprentices are not taught.[73]: 371 Professionals now send the hides to industrial-scale leather factories instead.[73]: 371 Commercial production of handmade embroidery has also ceased in Urfa, although many women continue the craft for dowry purposes.[73]: 369

Limestone quarrying

[edit]

There is an abundance of limestone in the Urfa area, and it has been quarried extensively since ancient times for use as a building material.[74]: 1–3, 5–7 This limestone, known as Urfa limestone, was mostly deposited in Eocene through Miocene times (about 56-5 million years ago).[74]: 8 It has a light, whitish-yellow ochre color.[74]: 3, 10 When freshly extracted from the quarry and still rather moist, Urfa limestone is relatively soft and can easily be cut with a handheld saw.[75]: 489–90 Once exposed to the atmosphere, though, its surface gradually hardens so that it makes a suitably strong building material.[75]: 490

Urfa limestone has been quarried for human use since at least the Neolithic period: it was the main building material used at Göbekli Tepe, 12,000 years ago, and the prehistoric quarries and workshops at Göbekli Tepe are among the oldest in the world.[74]: 2–3, 8 On the southern edge of the rocky plateau, there are also traces of quarries dating back to ancient Roman times.[74] : 8–9 Many old quarries in the area were also dug underground, forming artificial caves.[74]: 5 The oldest of this type is the massive 4-story Basda quarry, although its precise age is unknown.[74]: 9

A number of active limestone quarries exist today in the Urfa area.[74]: 7–8 Much of the quarrying is done just west of the city, around the Evren Industrial Estate. [76]: 163 Şanlıurfa province's total limestone reserves amount to 62.2 million tons, and its industry has an annual processing capacity of 31,680 tons.[74]: 8 Many of the stone blocks quarried from the Urfa area are sent to Mardin and Midyat for processing.[74]: 5

Before the introduction of reinforced concrete structures, Urfa limestone was the main building material used for "major" construction projects in the area.[75]: 485 Many historical structures in the city were built with this limestone: the castle and city walls, the Ulu Cami, the Halil ür-Rahman and Rızvaniye mosques, and the Gümrük Hanı, as well as many of the old 18th- and 19th-century houses in the old town.[74]: 1–2, 5 It is also used in many contemporary buildings, such as the Mevlana mosque complex.[74]: 7 Especially since the start of the GAP in the 1980s, regional demand for Urfa limestone as a construction material has been increasing, particularly since it is cheaper than reinforced concrete.[75]: 485 It is also commonly used in combination with other building materials, such as aerated concrete and pumice blocks.[74]: 13 In addition to being used as a building block, Urfa limestone is also used for cladding on the outside of walls, as well as decorative finishing on indoor walls.[75]: 485 Its use is mostly regional; it is not used much outside the area.[75]: 485

Industrial zones

[edit]

Organized Industrial Zone

[edit]

The Organized Industrial Zone (Turkish: Organize Sanayi Bölgesi) is located 17 km west of central Urfa on the highway to Gaziantep.[77] Construction started in 1991.[77] The site consists of three areas covering over 1,700 hectares as of 2018.[77] It is home to about 250 companies and employs about 13,000 people.[77]

Evren Industrial Estate

[edit]

The Evren Industrial Estate (Turkish: Evren Sanayi Sitesi) is a Small Industrial Site located about 7 km west of central Urfa on the highway to Gaziantep.[78] It covers about 140 hectares and is home to about 1500 businesses.[78] It became operational in 1994.[78] Urfa's limestone quarries are also clustered around here.[76]: 163

Culture

[edit]

Main article: Culture in Urfa

Cuisine

[edit]

As the city of Urfa is deeply rooted in history, so its unique cuisine is an amalgamation of the cuisines of the many civilizations that have ruled in Urfa . It is widely believed that Urfa is the birthplace of many dishes, including Çiğ köfte, that according to the legend, was crafted by the Prophet Abraham from ingredients he had at hand.[79]

Meat-based dishes are a staple of everyday meals in Urfa.[80]: 85 There is a local saying, "There is no trouble where meat comes in" (Turkish: et giren yere dert girmez).[80]: 85 Foods like lahmacun and kebab are consumed daily by many people.[80]: 85 Ciğer kebabı, or liver kebab, is especially popular among poorer Urfalis, since liver is usually a relatively cheap meat.[81] Liver kebab is popularly eaten for either breakfast, lunch, or dinner.[81]

The walnut-stuffed Turkish dessert crepe (called şıllık) is a regional specialty.[82] According to legend, its sweet syrup was first made using molasses from the Hanging Gardens of Babylon.[80]: 86

Hospitality

[edit]

Urfali society traditionally places a great value on hospitality, and inviting guests over and sharing food with them has a special importance.[80]: 86 Locals attribute this to the prophet Abraham, who according to legend never dined alone — he always had guests over to share his meals with.[80]: 86 The locally common epithet "Halil İbrahim Sofrası" ("the tablecloth-like") depicts this characterization.[80]: 86

Literature

[edit]

Urfa has a long history of literature, going back to early Christian writers such as Bardaisan and Ibas of Edessa.[10]: 106 A prominent medieval writer from Urfa was the 9th century Arabic author al-Ruhawi, whose Adab al-Tabib covered the topic of medical ethics.[83]: 8 Later, from the 1600s to the 20th century, divan poetry became popular in Urfa.[10]: 107 The popularity of divan poetry in Urfa is unusual because, by the 1600s, Urfa was not a major center of learning that would typically be expected to produce a lot of poetry.[10]: 107 In all, 130 different Urfali poets are known from this period.[10]: 107 A few of them are Nâbî, Ömer Nüzhet, Admî, Fehim, Hikmet, Şevket, Sakıb, and Emin.[10]: 108 Many of them were Sufis, affiliated with orders like the Bektashis, Mevlevis, Naqshbandis, Qadiris, and Rifa'is; they gathered in places like the Hasanpaşa Medrese, the İhlasiye Medrese, the Hasan Paşa Medrese, the Sakıbiye Tekke, the Halil’ür Rahman Medrese, the Rızvaniye Medrese, the Dabbakhane Medrese, and the Eyyübî Medrese.[10]: 108 Urfali divan poets almost exclusively used the ghazala form, with almost no known examples of the qasida.[10]: 108

Traditional house architecture

[edit]

Urfa's old town has many old courtyard houses; many were built during a construction boom in the 19th century.[11]: 8 A typical Urfa courtyard house is centered around a high-walled courtyard that is closed to the street.[84]: 311, 6 Facing the courtyard is a porticoed antechamber covered by a roof and partially surrounded by three walls.[84]: 317 In Urfa, the name for this space is mastaba; elsewhere, the more general term is iwan.[84]: 317 Other typical rooms include bedrooms, a kitchen (tandir), a sitting room, or a water closet.[84]: 316–7 There is also a semi-basement called the zerzembe, which is used for winter food storage and is practically omnipresent in traditional Turkish homes in regions with hot climates.[84]: 316–7 The house as a whole, with its courtyard, mastaba, and other rooms, forms one integrated living space rather than each room being its own "isolated, independent" space.[84]: 318

An important consideration in domestic architecture is mahremiyat, which could roughly be translated into English as "privacy" or "intimacy" but which carries stronger implications.[84]: 313 This concept is especially important when it comes to relations between men and women – outside the extended family, interaction between men and women is restricted.[84]: 313 As a result, traditional Urfa houses are constructed in ways to prevent men outside from viewing the women of the household.[84]: 319–20 For example, doors facing each other, windows facing the street, and significant differences in roof elevation are all avoided.[84]: 313

Local Turkish dialect

[edit]

The Turkish spoken in Urfa has some features in common with the variety of Iraqi Turkmen spoken in Kirkuk, as well as some features owed to Arabic influence.[10]: 19 For example, the Arabic sounds 'ayn, ghayn, and qāf are pronounced the same in Urfa as they are in Arabic, which is not done in standard Turkish.[10]: 19

Education

[edit]

Main article: Education in Urfa

Harran University

[edit]

Harran University was established in Urfa in 1992 as an amalgamation of several different faculties that had previously been attached to two different universities.[85]

Former vocational schools

[edit]

Mekteb-i Sanayi

[edit]

By 1906, the presence of a vocational school in Urfa called the Mekteb-i Sanayi is attested.[86]: 189 It was used as a hospital for wounded fighters during the Turkish War of Independence.[86]: 189 This school stayed open after the war and is attested again in 1927, by then under the name of Urfa Male Industry School (Urfa Erkek Sanayi Mektebi).[86]: 190 This school's building was demolished in the late 1930s and the Halkevi building was built on its site.[86]: 190

Urfa Girls' Institute

[edit]

The Urfa Girls' Institute (Turkish: Urfa Kız Enstıtüsü), which opened in 1942, was an early vocational school teaching practical trades and general subjects to girls and young women.[87]: 421

Urfa Institute of Art for Boys

[edit]

The boys' equivalent to the Girls' Institute was Urfa Institute of Art for Boys (Turkish: Urfa Erkek Sanat Enstıtüsü), which provided vocational education to boys aged 12 to 17.[86]: 187

Health

[edit]

Old state hospital

[edit]

The old state hospital in Urfa was established by Ethem Bey in 1903 and became a public hospital in 1943.[88] This hospital eventually came to comprise four different buildings, serving as the A, B, C, and D blocks.[88] The A-block building, which was three stories tall, opened in 1962 and was originally dedicated to treatment of tuberculosis.[88] The B-block building opened in 1972 and had 200 beds.[88] The D block was for emergency care.[88] Demolition of the old state hospital, which was located in Atatürk mahalle of Haliliye district, was completed in 2022.[89] At the time of the demolition, the provincial health directorate was planning to build a new 150-bed children's hospital on the site.[89]

Şanlıurfa Balıklıgöl State Hospital

[edit]

The Şanlıurfa Balıklıgöl State Hospital (Şanlıurfa Balıklıgöl Devlet Hastanesi) was established in 1963 as a "Health Station" (Sağlık İstasyonu), and then became a dispensary in 1975.[90] In July 1983, it became the Şanlıurfa SSK Hastanesi and was operating as an inpatient facility with 150 beds.[90] In addition, a 5-story outpatient department building began construction in 1991 and then became operational in 1994.[90] It was renamed in 2005 to its current name.[90]

Şanlıurfa Training and Research Hospital

[edit]

The Training and Research Hospital (Şanlıurfa Eğitim Ve Araştırma Hastanesi) was established in 1973 with 125 beds.[91] Originally, it was a branch hospital under the State Hospital, until 1984.[91] From 1984 until 2004, it was a gynecology and pediatric hospital, and in 2004 it was split in two: the gynecology and obstetric hospital, which remained in the same building, and the pediatric hospital, which moved into the old State Hospital building.[91] In 2016, the two branch hospitals were combined together into the Training and Research Hospital in the current building due to a shortage of beds.[91] The current building, as of 2019, covers over 100,000 square meters and has 400 patient rooms (with separate beds and restrooms), 18 operating rooms (2 of which are set aside for "maternity emergencies"), a 180-person conference hall, and an 80-person training hall, as well as a helipad and a parking lot with 1,200 spaces.[91] The hospital covers gynecology, pediatric, and adult healthcare.[91]

Mehmet Akif İnan Training and Research Hospital

[edit]

The Mehmet Akif İnan Training and Research Hospital (Mehmet Akif İnan Eğitim ve Araştırma Hastanesi) opened in 2004 and handles as many as 3,500 to 6,000 patient applicants per day.[88] It has 500 beds (rooms have 1, 2, or 3 beds, as well as their own restrooms) and a conference hall that can seat 156 people.[88] There is a blood center, a dialysis unit, and an intensive care unit, as well as a physical therapy unit for outpatients.[88]

Transport

Şanlıurfa GAP Airport is located about 34 km (21 mi) northeast of the city and has direct flights to Istanbul, Ankara and Izmir. The main highway from Gaziantep to Diyarbakır now bypasses Urfa on the northwest.[11]: 8

Construction of the first phase of a planned four-route, 78 km network of trolleybus lines began in late 2017,[92] and the first of 10 bi-articulated trolleybuses built by manufacturer Bozankaya was received in September 2018.[93] However, work on additional vehicles was suspended because of various problems,[94] and in 2020 the single vehicle delivered in 2018 remained the only trolleybus completed.[95] In late 2020, the original order for 10 bi-articulated vehicles was replaced by one for 12 standard-articulated vehicles, and the first of these was delivered in April 2022.[96] The trolleybus line opened for service on 28 April 2023, by which time six of the 12 vehicles had been received.[97] However, because of earthquake damage to certain streets in February 2023, among other factors, several changes were made to the planned route after completion of the overhead wiring and other infrastructure such that, after the line's opening, the vehicles are operating as trolleybuses on only about 600 metres of the now-7.1-km route.[98] The trolleybuses are able to operate on battery power on sections of the route that are not equipped with overhead wires and recharge their batteries during an extended layover at the terminus.[97][98]
